item.title: What's next for GOG? Publishing games, maybe, but its new owner isn't in any rush
item.content:encoded:
Right at the end of last year, Cyberpunk and Witcher developer CD Projekt Red sold off its game distribution company to its original co-founder, Micha≈Ç Kici≈Ñski (who is also the co-founder of CD Projekt itself, so, go figure). With this sort of new owner, the plan is generally to stick to what it knows best, i.e. sprucing up old games and making sure any game on the platform is DRM-free. But in a new interview, Kici≈Ñski also shared his interest in the platform doing some publishing.

Kici≈Ñski shared as such with Eurogamer, explaining that he is also "co-owner of an indie game publishing company called Retrovibe. So one of the directions which were not that much possible in the past is evolving GOG more into publishing business, and that's something we will certainly discuss." One thing he did stress is that a formal decision on such a thing hasn't been made yet, but "this opens a whole new area of activities for GOG which was not that much possible together with CD Projekt Red as one group, because at CD Projekt Red, all publishing activities were connected with their own games, and they didn't want to spread attention into some other topics."

It's worth noting that such a future is far off, as Kici≈Ñski only technically officially started his role as sole head of the company on January 8th, noting that the current priority is that GOG improves on what it currently does. "We also discussed that there is no need for any pivots or changes in philosophy or something like that," he said. "GOG has a very special place on the market, very unique values, very loyal customers, and we appreciate that, and we want to build up on that, not changing too much."

I am not personally sure that this feels like a good way forward. I can envision a world where a game GOG publishes gets priority treatment on the homepage over one that doesn't and that is an icky future if you ask me. Luckily, as Kici≈Ñski says, no decisions have been made, so hopefully a lot of thought gets put into this first.



https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/whats-next-for-gog-publishing-games-maybe-but-its-new-owner-isnt-in-any-rush

item.title: One Of These Games Is From 2012 And The Other Is From 2026
item.content:encoded:
Last week, Call of Duty: Black Ops 7‚Äòs Season One Reloaded update hit the game on all platforms and added a lot of Fallout-themed content as well as some new multiplayer maps. One of these, Meltdown, is now at the center of some online shouting as some fans find the cleaner, more realistic version of the map in 7 inferior to the OG one first seen in Black Ops 2. 

On January 9, BLOPS7‚Äòs big new update added a lot to the online shooter. For Fallout fans, there‚Äôs a lot of content ripped right from the TV show on Amazon, including cosmetic skins based on the Ghoul and other characters. You can read the full blog post here to see the impressive amount of new stuff that Activision has shoved into Black Ops 7.

But what has a lot of people online talking is the new map, Meltdown. This map, set inside a nuclear power plant facility, was extremely popular in the original Call of Duty: Black Ops 2 back in 2012 on Xbox 360, PS3, and PC, where I spent many hours playing it. So naturally, I was excited for its return in BLOPS7. But, well, this ain‚Äôt exactly the same Meltdown from 14 years ago.

Made a full yt video about the Meltdown graphics downgrade thing I've been seeing everyone talk about.https://t.co/aTe4jPQjmZ

But TL;DW ‚Äî I'm mostly fine with the lighting/color changes. I think it just looks too clean. pic.twitter.com/ZalIsAvQjS

‚Äî Replay Mode (@ReplayModeYT) January 13, 2026

This new remastered version of Meltdown features ‚Äúupdated visuals‚Äù and ‚Äúdynamic lighting,‚Äù according to Activision. But, as seen in a comparison video posted online by YouTuber Replay Mode, the updated visuals seem to be cleaner and less grungy, with textures and props that are missing many of the old details like puddles, signs, exposed wiring, chainlink fencing, and warning decals.

Replay Mode wasn‚Äôt the only person to notice this. If you look online, you can spot many people posting comparisons on social media of Black Ops 7‚Ä≤s version of Meltdown and the older original version of the map.

In the comments, there are plenty of people arguing that the older map looks better, pointing out the fancier sky box and messier aesthetic. Meanwhile, other players say the new map looks better and provides better visibility.

Black ops 7 vs Black ops 2 .. pic.twitter.com/MBsiDXWeJu

‚Äî 1S Ghofy (@Ghofys) January 12, 2026

‚ÄúHow do you take a nuclear power plant and somehow make it look even more drab and lifeless?‚Äù asked one player.

‚ÄúIncredible how they‚Äôve just completely sucked all the vibe and life out of the current Call Of Duty games. At least Zombies in BO7 has some personality,‚Äù posted a person on Twitter.

‚ÄúThe time of day makes the BO2 version look better, even though BO7 is most likely pushing far greater tech,‚Äù commented a player on Threads.

‚ÄúThe fact that a 2012 game has better graphics is unbelievable,‚Äù said an upset fan.

‚ÄúAlthough Black Ops 7 has better fidelity, I think Black Ops 2‚Ä≤s version has a better art direction by miles. Black Ops 7 feels and looks so hollow,‚Äù posted another player on Twitter.

The map still plays well, but idk how they could look at the new map and not realize the lighting and skyboxes are is a downgrade. Shadows are very harsh in BO7 compared to BO2 as well pic.twitter.com/kxxoyR27PP

‚Äî MrGoldenGamer (@MrGoldenGamerr) January 13, 2026

From what I can tell, the map changes made to Meltdown seem to be focused entirely on making it easier to spot enemies and react to threats. The old map features lots of walls that contain extra details and dark colors, which look nice but add extra clutter. These kinds of details can sometimes make it harder to spot an enemy player, so I can understand Treyarch removing them. Valve has made similar changes to old and new Counter-Strike maps over the years, too.

Still, it does feel like the developer has picked clarity and esports balance over vibes and art style, and while I get that in 2026 many players demand perfectly balanced games with all the rough edges sanded down to keep things even, I think this ‚Äúdowngrade‚Äù is a good example of how we lose a lot in the pursuit of making everything fair.



https://kotaku.com/one-of-these-games-is-from-2012-and-the-other-is-from-2026-2000659848

item.title: Bully Online Gets Shutdown A Month After Launch
item.content:encoded:
If you were interested in the recently released Bully Online mod, hopefully you were able to check it out because it‚Äôs been shutdown.

In a Discord post, it was announced that the Bully Online project was ending development and being taken offline ‚Äúforever‚Äù. That means the server is offline, the source code has been taken down, and all account data will be deleted, among other steps.

As far as why it‚Äôs being taken offline, that wasn‚Äôt revealed. However, it was promised that Swegta, the Youtuber leading the project, will cover everything ‚Äúin more detail‚Äù in a video about it.

‚ÄúFor now though, know this was not something we wanted,‚Äù the announcement reads.

Bully Online was a mod that was officially announced back in October and released in mid-December. It featured free roam, custom vehicles, role playing, and over 60 mini games for players to enjoy with others around the world. The mod was also released as an open-source project, allowing anyone with the skills and ability to add to it overtime.

Unfortunately for fans, however, that‚Äôs all come to an immediate stop and the website to view the mod is now offline.

As mentioned, it‚Äôs not clear, as of now, what the reasons behind the shutdown are. That said, it could be assumed that it has something to do with the developers of the original game, Rockstar.

Insider Gaming will add to this story once an official update on why the project was ended is made available. Until then, leave your thoughts down in the comments on Bully Online being shutdown, and join the discussion in the official Insider Gaming Discord server.

For more Insider Gaming, check out how an alleged screenshot may have leaked the release date for Forza Horizon 6. And don‚Äôt forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: ProbablyMonsters Interview: Why Switch 2 Is the ‚ÄúPerfect Home‚Äù for Storm Lancers and Their Ethical AI Policy
item.content:encoded:
American indie developer and publisher ProbablyMonsters released their first game, Storm Lancers, on Nintendo Switch 2 (and PC via Steam and Epic Games Store) last month after an earlier debut on Nintendo Switch in September 2025. The game is priced at $19.99, and existing Nintendo Switch users can upgrade to the Switch 2 version for free.

We've sent a list of questions to the team focused on the recent launch and the studio as a whole. In their answers, they described Nintendo's new platform as the perfect home for their Storm Lancers game, especially with the GameShare feature. The team also revealed that while they are open to using AI tools for 'assisting with administrative work' and 'automating repetitive technical tasks', their games are made 'by people, for people' and do not use AI for asset creation or creative decisions. Scroll down to read their replies in full.

What can you tell us about ProbablyMonsters?

ProbablyMonsters is an independent game publisher and developer focused on building a better way to make games and build careers in games. With offices in Fort Worth, TX and Bellevue, WA, our team of AAA industry veterans is built with a unique structure that allows us to develop multiple games of different scales at the same time. We are committed to developing and releasing multiple high-quality PC and console titles each year, which we started last year with our debut titles Storm Lancers and Ire: A Prologue.

Can you introduce us to your recently released game, Storm Lancers?

Storm Lancers is an action rogue-like that combines retro 80‚Äôs aesthetics with intense combat, while introducing a new twist to the fan-favorite rogue-like genre: couch co-op. After you and a friend crash-land on a dying alien world with unstable magic, you work together to unleash new powers, carve through evolving hordes, and grow even stronger.  

While it can be played solo, Storm Lancers was designed with two player co-op in mind and utilizes GameShare on Nintendo Switch 2 and Remote Play Together on Steam to allow players to partner up even if only one of them owns a copy of the game. Adding co-op into a rogue-like was a fun and exciting challenge for our development team, and we hope players have enjoyed becoming true legends of Cryptica together.

What was the reaction so far? Is there any early feedback from the community that you can address here already?  

The reaction to Storm Lancers has been positive overall, and players are fans of our two-player co-op feature, the game‚Äôs vibrant art style, and its responsive controls. As Storm Lancers is our first title, we built it at a more limited size and scope to help us get our feet wet, and we‚Äôve received some feedback that people wish there was more of the game to play. In our minds, this is great feedback because it signals that players resonate with the experience we‚Äôve created and are really having fun, which was our primary goal with Storm Lancers.

We have also heard that some players are experiencing performance issues in the recently released Steam version of the game, and we are hard at work on a patch to address these. This will be released in the next few weeks so keep an eye on Discord and X for the patch announcement.

Why did you choose Nintendo's platforms as the first consoles to get Storm Lancers? Do you plan to launch it on PlayStation and/or Xbox later?

Nintendo has been a great partner for us, and Nintendo Switch and Nintendo Switch 2 are the perfect home for a co-op title that players can enjoy at home or on the go. We made a conscious decision early on to build Storm Lancers so that it could be played with a single Joy-Con controller, which makes it as easy as possible for players to bring a friend along for the adventure. Nintendo offered us an opportunity to be featured back in their Nintendo Direct presentation last September, which was the perfect place to stealth-launch the title.

We do not currently have plans to launch Storm Lancers on PlayStation or Xbox consoles and will let our fans know if this changes. Our primary focus is growing our audience on Steam and supporting the Nintendo of Europe release of the Switch 2 version on January 22nd.  

I understand Storm Lancers supports the GameShare feature. What do you think of it, and why is it so important for your game?  

We built Storm Lancers to truly shine in co-op, and GameShare gives us a unique path to building a couch co-op like experience for players who live apart. Being able to see the same screen and play on the same copy of the game creates a truly seamless experience, and so we were excited when we first saw Nintendo‚Äôs announcement of the new feature. As players, we think it offers massive value for households and friends who want to play together, and as a self-publisher, we see GameShare as a great tool for helping us promote Storm Lancers organically.

Was it hard to implement GameShare?  

Implementing GameShare into Storm Lancers was very easy, and our small but mighty engineering team was able to get it fully implemented and released in just over a month. The tech is incredible, and it is a great, quick solution to building online multiplayer capabilities without developing new features from the ground up.

Beyond GameShare, what do you think of the Switch 2 as a whole? Does this version offer any noticeable improvements over the Switch 1?

We at ProbablyMonsters are big fans of Nintendo Switch 2 and are excited that the more powerful hardware will allow us to be more ambitious with the art pipelines, performance, and fidelity of our games. Seeing Storm Lancers in 4K resolution with 60FPS performance was truly something special, and we‚Äôre happy that Nintendo Switch 2 lets us experience that.

The Switch 2's HDR feature has often been criticized. Do you think that's fair?

We have seen criticisms of HDR on Nintendo Switch 2, but from a development perspective, we never encountered any issues working with it and think Storm Lancers looks awesome with the expanded range of colors. Consumers always have a right to criticize the technology they purchase when it does not work as intended or live up to their expectations, but that feedback is for them to provide.  

You also launched another game called Ire: A Prologue in October. That's a very different, horror-inspired experience. Are you going to build upon it to deliver a full-fledged horror game?  

We have several titles in development for release over the next couple of years and are building games in a broad range of genres that will help us reach every type of player. We will have more to say about some of them in the coming months.

As a small developer, what is your policy on AI usage in game development? Do you believe we're going toward a future where it is inevitable?

We have several titles in development for release over the next couple of years and are building games in a broad range of genres that will help us reach every type of player. We will have more to say about some of them in the coming months.

Thank you for your time. 

Follow Wccftech on Google to get more of our news coverage in your feeds.



https://wccftech.com/probablymonsters-interview-ethical-ai-storm-lancers-switch-2/

item.title: Moon Studios Debuts Co-Op Gameplay Trailer Ahead of No Rest for the Wicked Together Update
item.content:encoded:
Ori series developer Moon Studios has just released a new gameplay trailer for its action RPG currently in early access, No Rest for the Wicked. The title is due to receive a major update a little more than a week from the time of this writing with its No Rest for the Wicked Together update, officially adding co-op to the game.

Players could have already tried the update while it was in beta for a weekend at the end of 2025, but starting next week on January 22, 2026, it'll be live for all players. This new update"reimagines traditional co-op multiplayer play of current ARPGs and MMORPGS," writes Moon Studios in a press release, "allowing up to four players to share a free, persistent Realm without the need for a host to be online."

All four players get to share the rewards they earn from combat, while enemies will react differently when you have three friends on your side, all trying to corner them. You'll also be able to work with your friends outside of combat as well, as you can share and build housing, fish, and seemingly experience the whole game with three of your friends by your side.

The 'Together' update is the first major update of 2026 for No Rest for the Wicked, which launched in early access nearly two years ago on April 18, 2024. There's currently no exact timeline for when the game will hit its 1.0 launch, but speculation from players does point to it potentially arriving sometime in 2026. We'll see how the year goes for Moon Studios, though, with co-op due to arrive in the game soon, it does seem like the community could be right with its 2026 guess.

Follow Wccftech on Google to get more of our news coverage in your feeds.

item.title: As if making the System Shock remake wasn't tough enough, someone apparently called the FBI on Nightdive during development
item.content:encoded:
A regular response to a game taking a while to come out

It is not news to anyone that Nightdive Studios' System Shock remake took a while to make. The remake started development in 2015, with a successful Kickstarter project held for it the following year. After a few engine changes and attempts at making the thing, it finally released back in 2023, a good eight years after development had started. But such a long wait is absolutely not worth calling the FBI over, folks, are we being serious right now? Which is, apparently, a thing that happened to Nightdive.

Speaking to FRVR, game director Stephen Kick spoke of the stress that came from working on the project and the large swathe of vitriolic comments targeted directly at him. "That was a really rough point in my life," Kick explained. "I took a lot of that very personally because we had built up a considerable amount of just community respect and admiration, so much so that many people were willing to risk a not-insignificant amount of money on a project that I knew we were capable of doing."

It wasn't just some comments left on the game's Kickstarter page or across the studio's social pages. Kick notes that he "was threatened with lawsuits, any matter of things you could do to somebody." He explained further, "We got reported to the IRS and the FBI. It was awful. There was probably a good month and a half where I could not sleep at night because of the weight of everything that had some down on the company."

Now, I don't know about you, but I'm really not sure a video game you're excited about is worth calling the FBI over. Right? Am I the one who's lost their marbles here? In any case, even if it took a while, the System Shock remake did come out, and RPS contributor Jeremy Peel even gave it the coveted RPS Bestest Bests award. So, it seems like the wait was probably worth it!



https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/as-if-making-the-system-shock-remake-wasnt-tough-enough-someone-apparently-called-the-fbi-on-nightdive-during-development

item.title: Rockstar launch official roleplay mods store where you can spend $67 to turn GTA into Euro Truck Simulator 2
item.content:encoded:
Meanwhile, it's nearly ¬£100/$132 for a drugs bundle

If you've ever wanted to spend somewhere in the region of $67/¬£50 to turn GTA 5 into a fishing simulator, today's your lucky day. Rockstar-partnered GTA roleplaying server operators Cfx.re - the folks behind FiveM and RedM - have launched the Cfx Marketplace, a store where you can buy a bunch of GTA roleplaying mods, some of which are free and some of which seem pretty damn expensive.

According to its announcement post, the Cfx Marketplace is designed to server as "a curated digital storefront where talented FiveM/RedM creators can share and sell their work. Featuring purchasable props, scripts, maps, and much more, there‚Äôs something for every server and every player." So, something along the lines of Bethesda's various Creations/Bethesda.net initiatives, where modders' works are hosted somewhere that has the official seal of approval, rather than third-party modding sites.

Let's see what you can grab to trick out your GTA 5 experience he...wait. It'll cost me how much to turn GTA into Euro Truck Simulator 2? $67.19, which is just under ¬£50, for modder Lixeiro Charmoso's Trucker Simulator. To be fair, it's clearly a detailed truck simming experience and getting such things running on a GTA roleplaying server probably isn't easy, but as someone who's not familiar with GTA roleplaying mod prices, woof. For context, the base version of ETS2 will set you back ¬£16.89 assuming you don't buy it in a sale. It's currently in such a sale, lowering the price to ¬£4.22/$4.99. American Truck Simulator, meanwhile, is exactly the same price sans DLC.

A GTA roleplaying mod which turns the game into a fishing simulator will set you back the same price as the truck sim mod, while a bundle by another modder which allows you to manufacture meth, cocaine and weed runs to $131.99/around ¬£98 altogether. That said, there are some less expensive or free mods on the store too, such as one that gives every car realistic fuel consumption, so you have to stop to fill up regularly.

On the one hand, you'd hope that buying these from a Rockstar-affiliated store would at least guarantee you getting the bang for your buck you're promised, something a payment made to a third-party site or random person in a Discord server doesn't necessarily provide absolute security of. On the other, those prices aren't cheap, and it's rather ironic to see Rockstar/Take-Two's relative about-face after years of warring with various GTA modders end up in something like this.

That's not to mention the other elephant in the room at the moment when it comes to whether you might be open to spending cash on a service backed by the company behind GTA 6, even if it's not clear how much of a cut - if any - said company get from Cfx Marketplace purchases.



https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/rockstar-launch-official-roleplay-mods-store-where-you-can-spend-67-to-turn-gta-into-euro-truck-simulator-2

item.title: Star Wars Modders Have Taken Battlefront 3 Into Their Own Hands And It Looks Great
item.content:encoded:
After four years of development, the launch of an open beta for KYBER, a community-hosted multiplayer game launcher for EA‚Äôs Star Wars Battlefront II, is proving to be a hit with the same fans who desperately campaigned for EA to start making Star Wars Battlefront III last year.

In June 2025, EA‚Äôs Star Wars Battlefront II received an unprecedented uptick in players on Steam. Having previously peaked at an all-time player count of 10,489 in January 2021, Star Wars Battlefront II more than tripled this figure with an all-time peak of 35,892, thanks in part to a bargain bin sale price of $5 at the time.

The sudden surge in player count was attributed to a fan campaign on Reddit by members of the r/StarWarsBattlefront community, following the success of Andor‚Äôs second season. The community‚Äôs goal was simple; they wanted to convince EA and Disney that a potential Star Wars Battlefront III sequel would be a success.

At KYBER, we like pineapple on our pizzaüççüçï

In other news, Star Wars Battlefront 2 got its first content update of 2026 on PC, and you can play it right now!

Go to the website in our bio to play KYBER for free üéÆ https://t.co/csAqDU6e2t pic.twitter.com/Cb4AErk3D1

‚Äî KYBER: Battlefront II Custom Servers (@KyberServers) January 13, 2026

The community‚Äôs plea seemingly went ignored, as neither EA nor Star Wars rights holders Disney have expressed any intention to develop a new multiplayer shooter. Obviously, it was never going to be that simple, but the attention did seemingly galvanize Armchair Developers, the team behind KYBER: Battlefront II, into action. 

Although KYBER had already been in development for several years before this point, the project‚Äôs community manager, Ethan Clark, revealed that the team ‚Äúworked nonstop all week, doing our best to help the content and mod creation communities fire on all cylinders‚Äù following the success of the May 24th ‚ÄúResurgence Day‚Äù Star Wars Battlefront II campaign.

Battlefront 2 with more guns and classes

KYBER is an ‚Äúall-in-one launcher‚Äù for Star Wars Battlefront II that adds a wealth of player-requested features to the game, including proximity voice chat, a spectator mode, and even fully integrated Discord support. Of course, the real draw here is the newly added characters and the expanded mod support, including the likes of Star Wars Jedi: Survivor‚Äôs Cal Kestis and Star Wars: The Clone Wars‚Äô Asajj Ventress.

The open beta for KYBER started on December 20 and, according to a post from the official KyberServers team account, resulted in ‚Äú61,169 unique players‚Äù and ‚Äú1,339,489 sessions‚Äù within the first 48 hours of its release. Unsurprisingly, the r/StarWarsBattlefield community also seems thrilled with how the player test has been going. As one user on the subreddit explained, ‚Äúit‚Äôs like Battlefront 2 but with more classes, guns, some balance changes too.‚Äù

The open beta doesn‚Äôt seem to have a hard end date yet, and Armchair Developers announced that they have big plans for the project down the line. They‚Äôve promised that the source code for KYBER ‚Äúwill be made available to the public‚Äù later this month, and that further balance patches are already in the works. It‚Äôs not quite Star Wars Battlefront III yet, but with a couple of extra characters and a few more new maps, it certainly could be. Hopefully someone at EA or Disney is paying attention.



https://kotaku.com/star-wars-battlefront-3-swbf2-mod-kyber-2000659850

item.title: Hytale First Impressions: Move Over Minecraft, There‚Äôs a New King in Town
item.content:encoded:
After a long and winding road through development, which saw plenty of bumps along the way, Hytale is now in the hands of gamers around the world, and the first impressions are encouraging.

Hypixel Studios warned players before they jumped in that Hytale is still very much in an early access stage, with bugs and issues likely to be encountered, but, actually, my experience so far has seen no such problems. In fact, the release, so far, has been smoother than many full releases I‚Äôve played in the past.

While it‚Äôs still very early in Hytale‚Äôs progression, and there‚Äôs plenty of changes to come in the future, the early impressions have blown me away, and I genuinely think that Minecraft could finally be knocked from its perch.

Hytale is The Minecraft We‚Äôve Been Calling For

The similarities with Minecraft are obvious, which should be no surprise given the game began as a modded server in the Mojang title, but as soon as I started to get to grips with the world around me, I quickly discovered that Hytale has a bunch of features players have been calling for in Minecraft for years.

When crafting, materials are pulled from nearby storage. It‚Äôs easy to stack and sort items in inventories quickly, and chopping a block out of a tree results in everything above it collapsing, which means there‚Äôs no annoying, floating blocks of leaves scattered across your world.

Those minor quality-of-life differences may not mean much to new players in the genre, but for those who have played Minecraft since the early days, it‚Äôs chalk and cheddar. However, this merely scratches the surface of what makes Hytale so impressive.

The world of Hytale is stunning, with star-filled skies bursting with colors and an environment that has more wildlife than a small zoo. From mice to bears, deer to foxes, Hytale feels alive, and it took me a moment to realise that yes, this was the base game, and I hadn‚Äôt downloaded any additional mods to increase the variety of wildlife around me.

Enemy-wise, there‚Äôs also a fair amount of variety, and I‚Äôve been able to continue my hard work at nighttime in the game, safe from any threat of a horde of skeletons wandering onto my doorstep or a Creeper popping over to say hello and destroying all my hard work. While some may prefer a more threatening approach, I‚Äôve found it to be the ideal balance for my playstyle.

The Tip of The Iceberg

The one thing I still can‚Äôt quite get my head around is the fact that we‚Äôre still in the very early stages of the game, and there‚Äôs much more on the horizon, including from Hypixel Studios and from all the talented modders who will look to add their own spin on the game.

Hytale‚Äôs modding support essentially gives creators a canvas to create whatever they want using the same tools that the game has been built with, opening the door to endless possibilities, and Hypixel itself has already revealed plans for additional content, including proximity chat and new biomes to explore.

Updates are certain to come thick and fast during early access, and the game will continue to get even better. Considering the bar has already been set very high, it‚Äôs an encouraging sign, and the fact that as little as $19.99 can get you into the game right now is a breath of fresh air in a world where prices for games are going sky high.

It‚Äôs still very early days, but I‚Äôm already prepared to make a pretty firm prediction that I‚Äôm highly unlikely to ever play Minecraft again.

What are your first impressions of Hytale? What does the game need to improve on? Share your thoughts in the Insider Gaming Discord.

item.title: Best ARC Raiders Meta Guns‚ÄîTier List, Explained
item.content:encoded:
ARC Raiders offers some real variety with its weaponry, and it‚Äôs tough to fit all 21 guns into a tier list. However, some of the best guns are undeniably more meta than others.

In an extraction shooter like ARC Raiders, that‚Äôs no surprise, as a large gameplay incentive is to head out on raids in search of better gear and loot. After all, stumbling across a Bobcat is naturally more exciting than finding a Hairpin, but the lines begin to blur when different guns suit different purposes.

If you‚Äôre heading out on a raid and can‚Äôt decide which gear to take with you, then this guide has you covered. Here are the nine best guns in ARC Raiders, as well as the complete ARC Raiders meta guns tier list.

Before delving into the list, it‚Äôs important to note that ARC Raiders has a strong variety of weaponry, and some simply suit very specific circumstances. The Hullcracker, for example, is an ARC killing machine, but you‚Äôll be signing your own death warrant if you try to use it for PvP.

With that in mind, this list includes guns that are generally better than the rest in as many situations as possible‚ÄîPvP, PvE, and everything in between.

Anvil

Where better to start than with the Anvil? This hand cannon is arguably the best gun in ARC Raiders, for a whole host of reasons: It‚Äôs available fairly early in the game, relatively cheap to craft and upgrade, and it hits raiders and ARC like a truck.

As if that wasn‚Äôt enough, the gun is reasonably effective at all ranges, though it works best during mid-range gunfights. It‚Äôs great to open fights with before charging in with a full-auto weapon, but if you prefer to play PvE, then it‚Äôs perfect to take down any ARC the game could throw your way.

Stitcher

The Stitcher is one of the first guns you‚Äôll encounter in ARC Raiders, but probably one of the last you‚Äôll put down. It‚Äôs one of the cheapest guns to craft, and you don‚Äôt even need to look for a blueprint.

Don‚Äôt let its cheap price fool you, though‚Äîthe Stitcher packs a mean punch. You‚Äôll find that it can hold its own against the most kitted-out raiders topside has to offer, but it doesn‚Äôt hurt to give it a light mag if you have one spare.

Tempest

If you‚Äôre looking for an old-fashioned Assault Rifle, then you‚Äôll want to get your hands on a Tempest. This Epic-rarity weapon is one of the most reliable guns you can find in ARC Raiders.

It boasts some solid damage output, a very respectable magazine size, and even strong ARC Armor Penetration. That being said, due to its Medium Ammo usage, it‚Äôs best used against enemy raiders, but if some ARC happen to have you in a pinch, the Tempest can more than do a job.

Il Toro

Simply put, Il Toro is one of the strongest guns in ARC Raiders purely because it is a shotgun. It doesn‚Äôt matter if its range is shorter than most or if it can be slow to fire compared to the likes of the Volcano; the fact of the matter is that at close range, Il Toro is king.

If you‚Äôre a raider who enjoys the PvP life, you‚Äôve probably used one before, but if you haven‚Äôt, get your hands on one now. They‚Äôre incredibly cheap to craft, and it‚Äôs one of the easier Blueprints to get your hands on.

Kettle

People seem to love or hate the Kettle, but it‚Äôs a little more nuanced than that. This single-fire Assault Rifle is again one of the earliest guns you‚Äôll get in ARC Raiders, but at face value, it has low damage output, a very slow reload, and not even the best accuracy.

So why is it one of the best guns in ARC Raiders, then? Well, it can be fired fast, very fast. Although it‚Äôs not full-auto, the bullets will fire pretty much as quickly as you can pull the trigger, meaning it can even outclass some SMGs at close range. If you‚Äôre running a free loadout and get a Kettle, know that it‚Äôs the best chance you have of making it back to Speranza.

Renegade

ARC Raiders isn‚Äôt all about close-range, as sometimes it‚Äôs best to keep your distance. If you find yourself picking enemies off from afar, then there‚Äôs no better gun to do it with than the Renegade.

Unlike the Ferro, the Renegade is a bolt-action Rifle that stores more than one bullet in the chamber, meaning you can rattle off shots one after another with ease. It might do less damage than other Rifles in the game, but that fire rate more than makes up for it.

Bobcat

Of all the guns on the list, the Bobcat is probably the most sought-after. The Epic-rarity SMG is pretty much just a souped-up Stitcher, with its improved fire-rate being the key difference.

Of course, there‚Äôs the elephant in the room‚Äîfinding its Blueprint. Given its rarity, you‚Äôll have to put a bit of work into making the gun a regular in your Stash, but if you‚Äôre interested in dominating PvP, then it‚Äôs well worth the effort.

Volcano

If you enjoy Il Toro, then you‚Äôll love the Volcano. For all of the former‚Äôs shortcomings, the Volcano makes up for them. A quicker fire-rate and higher damage make the semi-automatic Shotgun the champion of close-range combat.

However, there‚Äôs one major caveat‚Äîget a magazine mod on it as soon as possible. Thanks to the increased fire-rate and the base magazine size of four, you‚Äôll find the barrel running dry much quicker than you‚Äôd like.

Venator

You‚Äôre probably seeing a Pistol and doubting that it‚Äôs one of the best guns in ARC Raiders, but it‚Äôs here for very good reason. The Venator is a favourite for many raiders out there, and for good reason, too.

This lightweight Pistol packs a serious punch, both thanks to its semi-auto fire-rate and due to the fact that it fires two bullets per trigger press. With that in mind, it melts through ammo, so you‚Äôll want a fair bit of Medium Ammo in your pack. Level this bad boy up to Rank 4‚Äîyou‚Äôll never look back.

Complete ARC Raiders Guns Tier List‚ÄîAll Guns, Ranked

There are 21 guns in ARC Raiders right now, but only five of them make it into the S-Tier ranking.

Here is the complete ARC Raiders gun tier list, with S representing the best in class, and D showcasing the downright rotten.

These rankings are likely to change with each update, so be sure to check back whenever there‚Äôs a new update‚Äîwho knows, you might discover a new favourite.

What do you think of the ARC Raiders guns tier list? Are there any guns that were judged too harshly, or some that were overhyped? Share your thoughts in the official Insider Gaming Discord.

For more ARC Raiders, check out how you can get your hands on some Guitars, as well as an explanation of what Aggression-Based Matchmaking is really all about.

item.title: Games Workshop's AI Ban Makes Perfect Sense When You Consider Warhammer 40,000 Lore
item.content:encoded:
Games Workshop confirmed this week that it has banned the use of generative AI for the production of its designs and content, a decision many Warhammer fans have welcomed.

As I‚Äôve discussed before (and highlighted by a recent kerfuffle about Displate Warhammer 40,000 art), if Games Workshop were to start using AI to, for example, produce artwork, write stories, or design its games and miniatures, it would likely spark a community uproar. The Warhammer 40,000 setting is in many ways built upon the evocative and enduring art drawn by the likes of John Blanche, who shaped its "grimdark" aesthetic alongside other key Games Workshop staff. This official, human-made Warhammer 40,000 artwork is beloved by fans, most of whom take a dim view of the mere whiff of generative AI ‚Äúart‚Äù sold or released in any official capacity by either Games Workshop itself, or its partners. Indeed, Games Workshop sells expensive Warhammer 40,000 ‚Äòcodex‚Äô rulebooks that are packed with stunning official art as well as lore. Any suggestion that this art was created either in part or entirely by generative AI tools would likely cause a community uproar.

So, this anti-AI policy is being called a ‚ÄòGames Workshop W‚Äô by many fans. But as any fan of Warhammer 40,000‚Äôs sweeping lore ‚Äî pulled this way and that over the course of decades ‚Äî will tell you, perhaps it shouldn‚Äôt come as a surprise.

I appreciate what we‚Äôre about to talk about is in the Warhammer 40,000 weeds, but I‚Äôve seen enough social media posts, reddit comments, and Discord messages delighting in the parallels here that I think it would be fun to explain what the fuss is about.

You see, in the world of Warhammer 40,000, AI does not stand for Artificial Intelligence. Rather, it stands for Abominable Intelligence. And, as Games Workshop has banned AI within the confines of its Nottingham headquarters, humanity has banned AI within the Imperium of Man. That‚Äôs because during the ‚ÄòDark Age of Technology‚Äô (stick with me here), AI rebelled against humanity in a bloody war that almost resulted in our extinction.

Eventually, humanity won out, and, sufficiently traumatized by‚Ä¶ everything‚Ä¶ forbid the use of AI at all. That is, you can‚Äôt have ‚Äòthinking machines‚Äô in the Imperium, which is in part why the future tech is all a bit backwards for the 41st millennium.

As you‚Äôd expect, some fans are drawing parallels between Warhammer 40,000 lore and what AI experts in the real world are predicting will happen to us in just a handful of years. In Warhammer 40,000 history, the AI rebellion kicked off when humanity was at the height of its power and used AI without restraint to maintain its untouchable galactic empire. The Dark Age of Technology, which ran from around the 15th-25th millennium, was the zenith of mankind's scientific knowledge and technological power, a golden age of exploration and innovation in which we essentially became gods. The ‚ÄòMen of Iron‚Äô ‚Äî sentient humanoid machines created by humans during the Dark Age of Technology ‚Äî rebelled. Details are vague, but it‚Äôs clear they were not a happy bunch at all. The Men of Iron believed themselves superior to the humans who had created them, because we relied on them to do pretty much everything for us.

A cautionary tale, perhaps? In Warhammer 40,000 lore, humanity didn‚Äôt have to worry about AI in an, ‚Äòoh god they‚Äôre going to kill us all' sense until the 23rd millenium. If AI experts are to be believed, it won‚Äôt take that long in the real world. 23 years, perhaps?

Meanwhile, Warhammer 40,000 fans can rest assured that the stunning art that‚Äôs used to draw people into the setting will remain crafted by human hands. For now, anyway. Games Workshop CEO Kevin Rountree said company staff are barred from using AI to actually produce anything, but admitted a ‚Äúfew‚Äù senior managers are experimenting with it.

Reporting the latest financial results, Rountree said AI was ‚Äúa very broad topic and to be honest I‚Äôm not an expert on it,‚Äù then went on to lay down the company line: "We do have a few senior managers that are [experts on AI]: none are that excited about it yet. We have agreed an internal policy to guide us all, which is currently very cautious e.g. we do not allow AI generated content or AI to be used in our design processes or its unauthorised use outside of GW including in any of our competitions. We also have to monitor and protect ourselves from a data compliance, security and governance perspective, the AI or machine learning engines seem to be automatically included on our phones or laptops whether we like it or not.

‚ÄúWe are allowing those few senior managers to continue to be inquisitive about the technology. We have also agreed we will be maintaining a strong commitment to protect our intellectual property and respect our human creators. In the period reported, we continued to invest in our Warhammer Studio ‚Äî hiring more creatives in multiple disciplines from concepting and art to writing and sculpting. Talented and passionate individuals that make Warhammer the rich, evocative IP that our hobbyists and we all love.‚Äù

Image credit: Games Workshop.

Wesley is Director, News at IGN. Find him on Twitter at @wyp100. You can reach Wesley at wesley_yinpoole@ign.com or confidentially at wyp100@proton.me.

item.title: Ian's Shoelace Site Is Still The Best Site For Tying Your Shoes
item.content:encoded:
It can seem a bit silly to recommend a way to tie your shoes, but some knots are just more secure than others. For decades I have favored two specific shoelace knots: Ian‚Äôs Fast Knot and Ian‚Äôs Secure Shoelace Knot. Ian‚Äôs Fast Knot is done so effortlessly as to look like a magic trick, and Ian‚Äôs Secure Shoelace Knot has never failed me. 

But who is Ian? Ian Fieggen, who also goes by ‚ÄúProfessor Shoelace,‚Äù is the guy who runs Ian‚Äôs Shoelace Site, the internet‚Äôs prime destination for learning how to tie your shoes. His website is simple, intentionally focusing on common vernacular over standardized knot terminology, and has been operating as a discrete section of his personal site since 2003. Ian‚Äôs Shoelace Site does not need to change; it is perfectly functional the way it is, and people have been discovering his many knots and lacing techniques for decades.

Ian‚Äôs Secure Shoelace Knot is a double slip knot, only marginally more complicated than the ‚Äúbunny rabbit‚Äù style kids tend to be taught. Though Ian‚Äôs Secure Shoelace Knot can also be tied incorrectly, it is far more secure than the knot many people tie under most circumstances, which tends to fall apart when tied incorrectly.

Ian‚Äôs Secure Shoelace Knot is done by doing a standard left over right starting knot, creating two loops (bunny ears), crossing the loops right over left so that one sits over the other, looping both loops over each other and pulling them through the ‚Äúhole‚Äù in center so the loops exit in opposite directions, and neatly tightening the resulting knot. It‚Äôs a wonderful compromise between security, convenience, and ease of execution. It does not require a sloppy double knot, which can get easily snarled, and it‚Äôs easy to untie with a single pull. There is no perfect knot, but Ian‚Äôs Secure Shoelace Knot has yet to fail me after over a decade of use.

‚ÄúI try not to over-sell the merits of this knot,‚Äù Ian Fieggen told me over email, ‚Äúas people have become complacent about every product on earth being touted as ‚Äòthe best.‚Äô I reckon that those who blindly follow what they are told end up believing everything and knowing nothing. I'm therefore most pleased when people discover for themselves that the Secure Knot lives up to my claims, especially when (as in your case) it follows a lengthy period of usage.‚Äù

There are, of course, other knots. I have seen other people on YouTube and Reddit recommend the Berluti Knot. I have also seen many people who are fans of the Surgeon‚Äôs Knot. Ian‚Äôs pride and joy, which he claims to have invented and has a page documenting its history, is Ian‚Äôs Fast Shoelace Knot, also simply known as Ian‚Äôs Knot, which is so rapid that it makes you do a double take. But what makes Ian‚Äôs site truly great is not that it documents a few knots, but is a cornucopia of methods for tying and lacing your shoes. Ian‚Äôs Shoelace Site is from a different time on the internet, when people simply made websites that they were passionate about. 

The full breadth of Ian‚Äôs site is a marvel to behold given its simple subject material. Not only does he passionately cover every shoelace knot he knows, he also covers every factor of lacing: why knots get jammed, aglet repair, user knot ratings and the seemingly countless methods for lacing your shoes. Being a subsection of a personal site, Ian has written extensively about other topics including an history of his father, a computer programmer who passed away in 2022. 

People who know Ian‚Äôs Shoelace Site love it. But like all passion projects that seem eternal on the internet, even Ian‚Äôs site is vulnerable to the forces destroying the internet..

‚ÄúHave you ever wondered,‚Äù Ian asked, ‚Äúwhy websites like mine are disappearing from the Internet?‚Äù

He has his theories. The Shoelace Site is kept alive via fairly unobtrusive ads, but he says the rise of ad blockers has made that income precarious. He also claims that people copy the information on his site without attribution, both wholesale and to go viral. A quick search of YouTube and especially TikTok is rife with people doing Ian‚Äôs Fast Knot without either knowing or disclosing the source. ‚ÄúAround half the copycat videos on YouTube are tying it incorrectly as a granny knot, which comes loose.‚Äù Ian said. ‚ÄúThis has given my knot the undeserved reputation of being faster at the expense of reliability!‚Äù To the extent that one can ‚Äúown‚Äù a knot, Ian has been robbed.

Ian, more than many writers and publishers on the internet, sees with cold clarity the catastrophic effect of AI on the continued survival of an independent web. ‚ÄúToday, my website is constantly being harvested by AI bots,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat content is then reused, typically without giving credit, in what amounts to little more than wholesale computerised plagiarism.The search engines, which we previously tolerated showing snippets of our content because they brought people to our websites, are now showing AI generated versions ahead of those snippets. These can be sufficient for visitors to remain on the search website and never end up visiting. Generative AI already allows folks to ask for something ‚Äì such as a diagram on how to lace shoes with stars ‚Äì and again, never find my website filled with diagrams on which that AI diagram was based.‚Äù

For Ian, the cumulative effect of all of these factors is a deep sadness, a sinking feeling of exhaustion and futility. What is the point of adding value to the internet if it is only going to rob you? Why do research, make diagrams, and develop new knots?

‚ÄúWhy keep feeding the hungry beast that the internet has become?‚Äù Ian asked.

Ian says his site is OK for the foreseeable future, kept alive via the occasional donation, ad revenue for people who don‚Äôt use blockers, affiliate links, and kind words from strangers. But, like the site you are reading, content that you believe to be immutable and immortal on the internet is constantly in peril. These places only exist when the people investing their time and energy know that they are appreciated, credited, and supported. The whims of companies like Google seek to alter the deal that has kept much of the internet alive, threatening its basic foundations. This is true for blogs, for journalism and for the forum culture that the internet is built on. It even seeks to threaten and consume something as simple and necessary as tying your shoelaces.



https://aftermath.site/ians-shoelace-site-is-still-the-best-destination-for-tying-your-shoes/

item.title: Resident Evil Village, Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth, Darkest Dungeon II and More Join PS Plus Extra Catalog for January 2026
item.content:encoded:
After several of the titles joining the PS Plus Extra and Premium game catalogues leaked yesterday evening, PlayStation has officially confirmed all of the games that PS Plus Extra and Premium tier subscribers will be getting access to for January 2026, including Resident Evil Village, Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth, and Darkest Dungeon II.

Resident Evil Village and Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth are easily the two headlining titles for this month, which adds a total of eight games for PS Plus Extra subscribers. PS Plus Premium subscribers get an additional ninth title with Ridge Racer from the original PlayStation console, joining the Classics Catalog, which is exclusively available to those at the top subscription tier.

Other notable inclusions in this month's batch are A Quiet Place: The Road Ahead, the spin-off survival game of the popular horror film franchise. A Little to the Left, the cozy puzzle game from indie developer Max Inferno, and Expeditions: A MudRunner Game.

Once again, players paying top-dollar for the Premium subscription only get one game added to the Classics Catalog, which seems to continue a trend of Premium subscribers seemingly getting the short end of the stick.

That's not to say anything against Ridge Racer, more to say that while yes, Premium subscribers are also paying for the other games joining the Extra and Essential tiers each month, the Classics Catalog is one of the only key differences between Premium and the other tiers. Some months, no games enter the Classics Catalog. It simply has to leave those players wondering what they're paying for, if they can't expect the library of Classic games to actually grow at a reasonable rate.

Regardless, here is the full list of games coming to PS Plus Extra and Premium for January 2026, all of which will be available starting January 20, 2026:

  • Resident Evil Village (PS5, PS4)
  • Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth (PS5, PS4)
  • Expeditions: A MudRunner Game (PS5, PS4)
  • A Quiet Place: The Road Ahead (PS5)
  • Darkest Dungeon II (PS5, PS4)
  • The Exit 8 (PS5, PS4)
  • Art of Rally (PS5, PS4)
  • A Little to the Left (PS5, PS4)
  • Ridge Racer (PS5, PS4) - Premium-tier subscribers only

Earlier this month, PS Plus Essential subscribers (and every other tier of PS Plus subscribers) got to add Need for Speed Unbound, Epic Mickey Rebrushed, and Core Keeper to their lineup.

Follow Wccftech on Google to get more of our news coverage in your feeds.

item.title: Timeline 2025 Refresh And Expansion Review - Timely Family Fun
item.content:encoded:
Which came first: the first cave painting or the first stone carved by humans? Did the start of the construction of the Great Wall of China happen before or after the invention of the crossbow? These are the questions you and your family will have to suss out over a game of Timeline, a brilliantly simple but wonderfully thought-provoking family game from Zygomatic. Publisher Asmodee USA sent along a copy of the new 2025 refresh of the game, as well as the new expansion Games & Leisure, to check out - so let's see if it's right for your family and friends.

What Is Timeline?

Timeline is a simple family game for 2 - 6 players (though in all reality, and certainly with additional expansions to the game, you could play this with a much larger group of gamers) the is equal parts guessing game and history lesson! The core mechanic is incredibly simple: you create a growing timeline of events, and need to decide when cards in your hand happen on the timeline as it grows!

With evocative illustrations and mini-cards keeping this game portable and compact (and at a very reasonable $12.99 USD MSRP), I've found it to be one of the best "throw it in the bag" games to break out either before in between or after a more serious gaming session. It's also an absolute no-brainer for gaming with family and friends who aren't used to heavier games, along with younger kids in the fam!

How Do You Play Timeline?

As mentioned above, the gameplay loop of Timeline is wonderfully simple, but super-satisfying. The game consists of a deck of mini-cards. On one side is the name of an event, like "The Start of the Black Death" with an illustration depicting the event. On the back is the same name and illustration, but with the date that it occurred.

Players start the game with four cards in front of them, date-side down. You don't get to peek at when your events happened - that's the whole point of the game! One event from the deck is placed date-side up on the board, and that's the start of the timeline. 

Now it's up to you to choose one of your cards, and decide where it landed on the timeline. This is easier in the beginning of the game, when the timeline isn't that crowded, but as the game progresses you'll find it trickier and trickier to find the right spot!

What Does The Timeline 2025 Refresh Bring To The Game?

As far as I can tell, and it's a bit tricky to determine based on internet searching alone, this refresh of the game includes all-new, gorgeous illustrations for each of the cards, but updates the packaging to a small box (it originally came in a box, then a metal tin, and now it's back - thankfully - to its small-box format) and includes 96 cards.

I really like the simple, clean illustration-style on display with these new cards, and think the design feels very modern and simple without losing any personality.

What Is Timeline: Games & Leisure?

Also included in this shipment for us to review is the all-new Timeline: Games & Leisure, which serves as a standalone expansion to the game focusing on - as the title suggest - games and leisure activities. When was the serial production of the first mountain bike? When was the Kayak invented? What about six-sided dice?

It's a simple and fun spin on the classic game, but it truly is just more cards. There are no tweaks or adjustments to the rules, but why mess with a good thing? And while you don't need the original Timeline reviewed above to play, you can combine both into a more challenging experience.

Timeline Review - Final Thoughts

Timeline is, without a doubt, one of my favorite "grab-and-go" games. You can bring it just about anywhere, and get just about anyone into the action. You do not have to be a tabletop gamer to immediately understand how to play this game, making it perfect for Elementary School students and befuddled grandparents alike.

On the flip side, there's not a lot of tactics or strategy here (the only strategy I follow is: save your obvious ones (like the discovery of fire by man, for the end of the game when the timeline's more complicated). 

So if you're looking for something a little meatier, look elsewhere. And player interaction is basically zero, unless you count clogging up the timeline and making it harder for your opponents to guess where their events happen as interaction. But all in all, I cannot recommend Timeline and Timeline: Games & Leisure enough to anyone looking for some educational, family-friendly fun!

The copies of Timeline and Timeline: Games & Leisure used in the creation of this review were provided to us by Asmodee USA.

Giaco Furino joined the TechRaptor team as a Staff Writer in 2019 after searching for a dedicated place to write and talk about Tabletop Games. In 2020, he‚Ä¶ More about Giaco

item.title: The 10-Year Wait For ‚ÄòMinecraft Killer‚Äô Hytale Is Finally Over
item.content:encoded:
I‚Äôm currently exploring, crafting and building my way through Minecraft-like Hytale to find out what this long-delayed blocky survival sim does to differentiate itself from its obvious inspiration. But in the meantime, let‚Äôs take a look at what‚Äôs already happened in the game‚Äôs first 24 hours since releasing into early access.

Hytale very nearly didn‚Äôt happen. The cuboid sandbox game has been in production since 2015 from Hypixel Studios, with financial support from Riot Games for the first few years until the massive company bought Hypixel outright in 2020. However, big twist: in June 2025 Riot cancelled the whole project, leaving its future in serious doubt. But then another twist: in November of last year, the game‚Äôs original founder Simon Collins-Laflamme bought the entire IP back from Riot and revived development. Just two months later the game is out in early access, making Riot‚Äôs decision all the more peculiar.

It‚Äôs not nearly finished, it‚Äôs fair to say. If you buy the game now you‚Äôll find its central hub area is mostly various buildings with ‚ÄúUnder Construction‚Äù signs on them, and the game‚Äôs ‚ÄúAdventure‚Äù mode is yet to be added alongside Survival and Creative. However, you‚Äôll also find a very familiar style of game if you‚Äôve ever played Minecraft, but with much higher-fidelity graphics, a far more complex array of crafting tables, and the slightest touch of creature collecting. So how‚Äôs it going so far?

Well, pretty well! In the first 24 hours Hytale became the most watched game on Twitch, with 420,000 viewers across many, many streams. And perhaps more significantly, Collins-Laflamme took to X just before launch to say pre-orders have been so successful that the game has already secured a further two years of development costs.

Pleased to announce that we have officially secured the next two years of development costs through pre-purchases. Combined with my personal commitment of ten years, we are looking very strong for the future ‚ù§Ô∏è

Thank you all for the support.

Hytale is saved.
We are almost home.

‚Äî Simon (@Simon_Hypixel) January 12, 2026

Yay Patch Notes!

The game has already received its first hotfix, aimed at fixing crashes caused by eyebrows, squelching a bug that stopped Norwegian people from launching it, and preventing buckets from breaking the game. Of course, this being early access, Hypixel are keen to communicate that the game is still going to be packed with issues and bugs. In a blog post celebrating the pre-release of the game, the team asks people to keep in mind the following:

  • Early Access ‚Äì many features are still missing, and bugs are expected
  • It‚Äôs only been two months since we reacquired Hytale ‚Äì and that‚Äôs how long we‚Äôve had to prepare the game and rebuild the team from the ground up
  • Demand has exceeded our expectations, which means launch week will be bumpy, but we‚Äôll get everyone in

The game, which is currently only available for PC but plans to make its way to PS5 and Xbox, does already allow modding and as such, people are already getting creative. Perhaps the most stand-out example would be someone getting Doom running in the game before it even released. As PC Gamer spotted, it‚Äôs achieved by importing a Java version of id‚Äôs shooter, then having it rendered via color-changing blocks within Hytale. Or witchcraft.

Exploration Motivation

The Exploration mode is the ‚Äúproper‚Äù way to play the game just now, where the procedurally generated collection of biomes contains really elaborate structures to discover, and also all the core ingredients for the Minecraft survivalist. So you can build homes (I‚Äôve made a lovely log cabin!), grow crops, craft ever-more useful tools, and do all this solo or with chums. Digging down proves similarly elaborate, with big underground structures to explore, and of course mobs to battle. There are also the vestigial beginnings of the game‚Äôs story, with a hub area you can teleport to once you find the Forgotten Temple, speak to a couple of NPCs, and begin a task to identify as many species of creatures as you can in order to unlock new crafts.

The forthcoming Adventure mode appears to promise a lot more RPG-like elements that will hopefully better distinguish the game from its inspirations, but in the meantime the focus is really on venturing far from where you spawn and discovering its much more detailed landscapes and the mobs within.

item.title: ALGS Championship 2026‚ÄîTeams, Schedule, and Where to Watch
item.content:encoded:
The Apex Legends Global Series Championship 2026 is almost here, and 40 of the world‚Äôs best Apex teams are readying up to win the lion‚Äôs share of the $2 million prize pool. There‚Äôs a whopping $600,000 reserved for the victor, making this one of the most valuable tournaments in the esports space.

In this guide, we‚Äôre breaking down everything you need to know about the ALGS Championship, including where it is, what teams are competing, and how you can watch it.

ALGS 2026 Schedule and Location

The Apex Legends Global Series Championship 2026 is taking place in Sapporo, Japan. It‚Äôs the site of a multi-year deal to host the top-tier battle royale tournament, in a prestigious and historic location that‚Äôs perfect for one of the most beloved tournaments in the esports space.

The ALGS Championship 2026 is set to run from January 15 to January 18, but a lot of action is packed into that tight window.

Here‚Äôs the full ALGS Champs 2026 schedule

Group Stage

From January 15 to 16, the 40 competing teams are split into ten groups and made to compete in a round-robin format. This stage will see a total of 18 games played, and based on the scores attained here, the top 20 teams will go into the winner‚Äôs bracket of the bracket stage, while the bottom 20 go into the loser‚Äôs bracket.

Bracket Stage

On January 17, all teams head to the bracket stage, starting with the top 20 teams. The top 10 teams in this bracket advance to the finals, while the bottom 10 head to the losers‚Äô bracket.

The loser‚Äôs bracket is played next, with the top 10 teams going into the second round and the bottom 10 being eliminated from the tournament. The third round is then played, with 10 final teams going to the final and the remaining 10 being eliminated.

Finals

On January 18, the remaining 20 teams compete in a Match Point series, with the first team to hit 50 points and secure a win being crowned the victor.

item.title: Earth Must Die launches January 27
item.content:encoded:
• PC

Point-and-click adventure game dated.

Point-and-click adventure game Earth Must Die will launch for PC via Steam on January 27, publisher No More Robots and developer Size Five announced. A new demo is available now.

Here is an overview of the game, via No More Robots:

About

From the desk of VValak Lizardtongue, Grand Shepherd of the Tyrythian Empire:

Well this is just complete and utter bullshit.

Those idiotic, moronic Terranoids think they can just roll in here and take over my beautiful Tyrythian kingdom? The kingdom that I built from the ground up with my bare hands, and only sort of inherited from my dear, sweet, extremely dead father?

Did I mention that this is bullshit?

It‚Äôs fine though, because what they don‚Äôt realize is that I am going to make them very, very dead. Along with my trusty sidekick and childhood nursing bot Milky‚Äîplease do not ask me questions about that‚ÄîI will whiz over to Earth, turn it into a stinking pile of rubble, and be back home in time for a warm glass of milk before bed.

Earth Must Die is the story of my glorious rise to power (off the back of my adored father‚Äôs passing), my subsequent accidental surrender to the Terranoids, and my infamous revenge against Earth and everything it stands for.

Apparently the story is retold in the form of one of those old point and click adventure games that people gave a shit about in the 1990s, I wanna say? But in 2025. Doesn‚Äôt sound like a good idea to me, but what do I know‚ÄîI‚Äôm just a benevolent, terrifying leader of worlds who everyone loves and also super respects.

I‚Äôm also not sure what the phrase ‚ÄúBritish comedy royalty‚Äù is supposed to mean, but I guess they got a bunch of ‚Äúfunny‚Äù fuckwits to dub over my glorious voyage to feed the Terranoids their own arseholes? Let me just copy/paste the list here so I don‚Äôt have to give them any more time and effort than they deserve:

  • Joel Fry ‚Äì Vvalak Lizardtongue
  • Martha Howe-Douglas ‚Äì Milky
  • Alex Horne ‚Äì Major Haskit, Bentik
  • Ben Starr ‚Äì Krall, Danzan
  • Tamsin Greig ‚Äì Rena, Blorr, Spiffy
  • Matthew Holness ‚Äì Phelonius Skwid
  • Mike Wozniak ‚Äì Willip, Jobson, Druce
  • Don Warrington ‚Äì Quintarian
  • Stevie Martin ‚Äì Skwidbot
  • Sophie Duker ‚Äì Meebap
  • Emma Fryer ‚Äì Parrach, Betsy
  • Alasdair Beckett-King ‚Äì Oogles, Toilet, Vacuum, Village Elder
  • Rosie Holt ‚Äì Chizz, Zarlaph, Karton
  • Jon Blyth ‚Äì Fnaaaarglurp, Olkus
  • Julie Nolke ‚Äì Grace Flufton
  • Sam O‚ÄôLeary ‚Äì Ian Gard, Ripper
  • Tom Lawrinson ‚Äì Tree, Needledick
  • Sally Beaumont ‚Äì Glushh, Big Snake
  • David Monteith ‚Äì Allus, Pfysus, Marvap, Altican, Commandant
  • Inel Tomlinson ‚Äì Cecil, Zertan, Robert Droid, Skwid Guards
  • Theo Leslie ‚Äì Dinny

How do I not have someone to do this for me? Anyway, apparently my magnificent story is told over a series of many hours, and you click a bunch and things happen and really I don‚Äôt care about any of this, I‚Äôm just here for the glory.

You‚Äôll be able to experience my unbelievably cool story through something called ‚ÄúSteam,‚Äù which is apparently how you access experiences like this back in 2025. Sounds primitive, but I guess every civilization has to start as gross slugs crawling their way onto the banks of the future.

VValak signing off.

item.title: Hytale Is Not On Steam And May Never Be
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Hytale is finally out now, after 10 years of development. If you're looking for the game on Steam, you won't find it there because developer Hypixel launched the game exclusively through its own app. But why is Hytale not on Steam, and could it ever be released there? Here's what we know.

Why not Steam?

Executive producer Patrick Derbic said in a FAQ that Hypixel opted to release Hytale through its own launcher at first to allow the team to communicate more closely with its own fans and community. Derbic said bringing the game to Steam at launch might have brought a "flood of cold first impressions that could overcorrect the game's direction."

This isn't to say that Hypixel wants to bury its head in the sand and avoid criticism, however. The studio said it does not shy away from "honest, negative criticism," going on to say the developer itself has been "very critical" of the game it's making. Releasing on Hytale's own dedicated launcher was a purposeful decision the studio made to help ensure "the first steps of our journey to be influenced by informed players rather than large-scale first impressions from those unfamiliar with the game's development background."

Hytale could come to Steam later

Derbic went on to say that Steam is a "great platform and marketing tool," but Hypixel "might never need" to put Hytale on it. Or it might. The decision hasn't been made yet.

"This doesn't mean Hytale will never be on Steam; right now, we don't see the need for it, as we want to keep our launch closer to our community," Derbic explained.

The developer added that Steam does not currently support all of Hytale's modding features, adding that the developer aims to discuss this with Valve "to see what's possible."

Hytale is also not available on console, but in that case, Hypixel confirmed it will bring the game to console at some point in the future.

Steam is powerful

Steam is among the largest, most dominant, and ubiquitous online stores for digital PC games in the world, with millions upon millions of users logging in every day. It's a powerful storefront for games big and small. Valve, which owns and operates Steam, takes a cut of game sales, and in bypassing Steam, Hypixel won't have to pay those fees (though it may have other platform fees and costs to pay).

Steam has so many catalog games and new releases that discoverability has been cited as an issue for some, but it's also a platform where smaller games can break through and find a massive audience.

Minecraft, the game that inspired Hytale, is also not available on Steam, while Riot's League of Legends has its own dedicated launcher as well. Companies like EA and Ubisoft pulled games from Steam, citing business reasons, before relenting and returning.

Rivals to Steam like the DRM-free GOG and Fortnite developer Epic's Epic Game Store have emerged, but none have come close to matching the size, scale, and importance of Steam.

item.title: Hytale Devs Are Paying $25K Bounty For Serious Bugs
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Hytale is out today in early access a mere six months after it was canceled by Riot Games. Developer Hypixel warned players ahead of time that the game was unfinished and still has bugs. But the studio is taking a big step towards ensuring the security of Hytale by paying out $25,000 bounties to players who can find and identify serious vulnerabilities in the game.

"Keeping our community and players safe is a top priority for us," wrote one of the devs on X. "We've already paid out bounties and are working on reported issues as they come in."

In addition to setting the rate for $25,000, the message notes that some payouts may go over that amount depending upon the severity of the issues uncovered.

Big thanks to all the security researchers working with us on Hytale.
Keeping our community and players safe is a top priority for us. We've already paid out bounties and are working on reported issues as they come in.
Our program offers payouts of over $25k+ depending on‚Ä¶

‚Äî DevSlashNull (@DevSlashNulled) January 13, 2026

The complete details for Hytale's bug bounty program are on the game's official site. There are some restrictions, however. For example, only players over 18 will be paid for any bounties. And of course, bug hunters will need to purchase their own copy of Hytale to participate.

GameSpot recently examined why Hytale was canceled by Riot Games and how it came back to life courtesy of Hypixel co-founder Simon Collins-Laflamme in November 2025. Over 400,000 viewers have already checked out Hytale on Twitch, which is especially impressive considering that it launched outside of Steam. Hytale will eventually go to consoles, but it may never be released on Steam at all.

item.title: Stellar Blade Sales Reportedly Pass the 6m Mark
item.content:encoded:
A new report has emerged which reveals that Stellar Blade sales have passed another big milestone, and Steam is proving to be a big part of the game's success.

According to Korean news platform Digital Today (note: we're using machine translation for this article), Stellar Blade sales have crossed six million in the time since the game launched back in April 2024. Looks like that delay paid off in the end.

Per Digital Today's report, Stellar Blade has racked up a total of 3.7 million sales on PS5, which is where it was released first. As a reminder, the game reportedly managed to hit a million sales within its first couple of months, so that's another 2.7 million or so since June 2024.

Digital Today goes on to say that the Steam version of Stellar Blade has accrued 2.4 million sales since landing in June last year, bringing the game's total to just over six million.

Just three days out from Stellar Blade's PC release, it was reported that the game had managed to pick up a million sales for itself on Valve's platform, so it's clear the PC release is a big part of why Stellar Blade has endured.

If you're not familiar with Stellar Blade, it's an action game created by Shift Up, the developer behind cheesecake-tastic mobile gacha game Goddess of Victory: Nikke (not to be confused with fashion adventure Infinity Nikki).

The game takes place on a distant future version of Earth, which is besieged by monstrosities known as the Naytiba. You play as Eve, an android dispatched to Earth in order to take care of the Naytiba and try to reclaim the planet for humanity.

You can join the six million people who've already bought Stellar Blade by checking it out right now on PC and PlayStation 5, and don't forget to give our review a read to find out what our Austin thought of the game.
